(Leans in closer to the picture, then pulls away quickly) Eww, its teeth are all yellow and pointy! (Wrinkles nose) And its nose is all big and lumpy. Its eyes...they look kinda mean. Like it's gonna eat someone. Or smash them! (Grins again) It looks angry and hungry! Can I be done now? My brain hurts.

"Yellow and pointy teeth" and a "big and lumpy nose" are great details! And you're spot-on about its eyes – they do look mean, angry, and hungry. You've really looked closely and described the troll very well.

Okay, just a couple more things. Can you describe the overall lighting in the picture? Is it bright and sunny, or dark and gloomy? How does the light affect the mood?

(Sighs loudly) It's dark, duh! (Points at the picture) There's not much light at all. Just some creepy light shining through the mist. It makes everything look even spookier, like a monster is gonna jump out at any second. Like in a horror movie! Can we PLEASE be done now? I want to draw dragons!

"Dark" is right! And "creepy light shining through the mist" is a perfect description. You're also right about how it makes everything look spookier, like a horror movie. You've done a great job noticing how the lighting adds to the mood.

Okay, one last thing: can you summarise what you see in the picture in one or two sentences? Imagine you're telling a friend who can't see it.

(Grumbling) Fine. Okay... There's a super ugly, giant troll in a creepy, dark forest with twisty trees and mist. It looks angry and hungry and ready to smash someone! Now, can I go? (Starts packing up their things)
That's a perfect summary! You've included all the most important details and captured the overall mood of the picture. You did a fantastic job describing it! <finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's describe this picture together! What's the first thing that catches your eye when you look at it?
(Confidently) A troll! It's a troll! (Points excitedly at the picture) It's... it's green. And BIG.
That's a great start! You're right, it's definitely a troll, and it's green and big. Can you tell me anything else about the troll? What is it doing or wearing?
(Looks away, fidgeting) Uh... it's got... clothes? (Stutters) Dirty clothes. And it's... standing? (Thinking) Yeah, standing in the woods. Are we done yet? This is boring.

Not boring! We're doing great. "Dirty clothes" and "standing in the woods" are excellent observations. Instead of "clothes" can you be more specific? What kind of clothes are they? What do they look like?
(Sighs loudly) (Rolls eyes) They're... brown. And ripped! (Grumbling) Like he fought a bear or something. Can I go now?

"Brown and ripped" is much better! You're really looking closely now. And "like he fought a bear" is a fantastic detail that shows you're thinking about the story behind the picture.

Now, besides the troll, what else do you see in the picture? Focus on the background this time. What does the place look like?

(Points vaguely at the picture) Trees. Lots of trees. And... (Stares blankly) Rocks? It's a forest. Duh. (Taps foot impatiently) Can we PLEASE be done now? I wanna go play video games. This is SO boring!

Okay, okay, not "just" a forest. Can you describe the forest a little more? Are the trees all the same? Are there any special colors or details you notice about the forest? Look carefully! What makes this forest... not just any old forest?

(Grumbling) Fine. (Squints at the picture) Uh... some of the trees are... glowy? (Shrugs) And there's, like, mist or fog everywhere. It's spooky. Is THAT good enough? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

"Glowy trees" and "mist or fog everywhere" are fantastic details! And "spooky" is a great word to describe the feeling you get from the picture.

Now, let's put it all together. Can you describe the picture to me using the details we've talked about? Try to paint a picture with your words.

(Sighs dramatically) (Muttering) Okay, fine. There's a big, green troll... wearing ripped, brown clothes like he fought a bear. And he's standing in a spooky forest with glowy trees and mist. There! Happy now? Can I GO?

Yes! That's a great description! You included the most important details: the troll, his clothes, the forest, the glowy trees, and the mist. You really looked closely and used your imagination. Excellent work! <finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's describe this picture! What's the first thing that catches your eye when you look at it?

Now, can you tell me anything else about the bird's appearance? Maybe look at its beak or its eyes. What do you notice?

(Looks away, fidgeting) Uh... it has a beak. (Stuttering) A yellow beak. Like... like all birds, right? And... (Thinking) big eyes. Black eyes. Is that all? Can I *please* go now? This is boring. (Sighs dramatically)

You're doing great! Yes, it has a yellow beak and big, black eyes.

Now, instead of focusing on individual features, let's think about how the bird *feels*. Does the bird look happy, sad, angry, or something else? Why do you think so?

(Rolls eyes) Happy. Duh. (Points aggressively at the screen) It's a cartoon! Cartoons are *always* happy! Look at it! It's just... standing there. Being happy. Can't you see that? I don't know why we have to talk about this so much. (Starts tapping foot impatiently)

Okay, I hear you. You think it looks happy. Why do you think it looks happy specifically? Is there something about its face, posture, or anything else that suggests happiness to you? Remember, look *closely*.

(Grumbling) Because... because it's smiling! (Points, almost jabbing the screen) See? A smile! Happy! Done! (Crosses arms and slouches in chair, glaring) I *told* you it was happy. You're wasting my time.
You got it! The smile is a great clue. Excellent. Now, can you see anything *behind* the bird? What's in the background?

(Sighs loudly) More... more colors. (Waves hand dismissively) Blue and green. Like... a blurry mess. Is it supposed to be the sky and grass or something? I don't care. Can we PLEASE be done? (Voice rising in frustration) I'm going to explode if I have to look at this stupid bird for one more second!

Okay, okay. You're right, it's a blurry mix of blue and green, possibly suggesting the sky and grass.

Now, let's put it all together. Can you describe the picture to me in one or two sentences, including the bird and the background? What would you tell someone who can't see the picture?

Yes, that's a good description! You included the important details: the happy bird, its colors, and the background.

(Scoffs) We looked at a stupid bird and said it was blue and yellow and happy! We wasted, like, a whole hour! (Starts walking towards the door) I'm leaving. This is ridiculous. (Slams door)

dialogue: Okay, let's describe this picture together. What's the first thing that catches your eye when you look at it?

dialogue: Okay, let's describe this picture! What's the first thing that catches your eye when you look at it?
Yes, you're right! It's definitely a bird. What can you tell me about the bird? What does it look like?
Okay, "blue" and "round" are good observations! Can you see anything else about its color? Is it *just* blue, or do you notice any other colors?
...There's yellow too. On its face. Is that all? Can I go now? (Starts fidgeting)
Yes, you're right, there's yellow on its face! Good spotting. Take another look... what about its eyes, what colour are they?
Okay, black eyes! Now, besides being round, what else can you tell me about the bird's body? Does it have any other features? Think about what all birds have.
You got it! It has wings. What else does the bird have that you can see? What does it need to stand and walk?
Feet. It has... uh... orange feet. Can we be done now? This is boring. (Sighs loudly)
Yes! Orange feet. Well done for sticking with it. Now, where do you think this bird is? Is it flying? Sitting?
(Stares blankly at the picture) I dunno. It's just... there. It's a picture.
I see what you mean. But, is the bird in a nest? Is it outside? Is it inside? Does the picture *look* like it's showing somewhere specific? What's *behind* the bird?
(Grumbling) It's a blurry background. Nothing. Just... blurry.
Okay, you're right, the background is blurry. But does that blurry background remind you of anything? Like a park, the sky, or something else? What colour is the blur?
It's... green-ish? Like grass maybe. So it's outside. Whatever. Can I go now? (Pushes chair back slightly)
Yes, you are right. Greenish, like grass, so it's probably outside! Ok, nearly there! Can you put all of that together into a few sentences to describe the bird in the picture?
Uh... it's a blue and yellow bird. It has black eyes and orange feet. And it's outside. (Stands up, ready to leave) Done!
Great job! You described the bird very well. You said it's a blue and yellow bird with black eyes and orange feet, and it's outside. <finish>

dialogue: Okay, let's describe this picture together. What's the first thing that catches your eye in the image?
That's a good start! You're right, it looks like a forest. What can you tell me about the character in the picture?
You got it! It *is* a guy. What does he *look* like? What is he wearing?
(Stares blankly at the picture) ...Blue shirt. And...shorts.
Good observation! He's wearing a blue shirt and shorts. Now, what is he doing in the forest?
He is walking! And what does he have with him that might help him explore?
Yes! He has a map. Why do you think he needs a map in the forest?
Exactly! Now, looking at the forest itself, what do you notice about the trees? Are they all the same?
Good! What's different about them? Think about their size or color.
Great! Some are bigger. Do you notice anything else about the forest - maybe about how it makes you feel when you look at it?
I understand you're feeling a bit bored. How about we try to make it more interesting? Does the forest look bright and sunny, or dark and mysterious?
Okay, bright. And does the character look happy or sad to be there?

It *does* matter! We're building a picture with our words. He looks happy. So, we have a happy guy with a map, walking in a bright forest with different-sized trees. Can you put all of that together into one or two sentences that describe the picture?
(Glares) ...A happy guy is walking in a bright forest with a map. Done.

Good job! That's a great description. You noticed the important details: the happy guy, the bright forest, and the map. We can also say that the trees in the forest are of different sizes. Now, can you try to say it all together, including this detail?
(Sighs loudly) A happy guy... uh... is walking in a bright forest with a map and the trees are different sizes. Whatever. Can I go now?
Excellent! That's a complete description of the picture. You did a good job selecting the details and putting them together. <finish>
